The investigators form a "Mathematics and Climate Research
Network." This is a framework for an intensive effort aimed at
bringing to bear the full power of modern applied mathematics and
statistics on the prediction and understanding of the Earth's
climate. The investigators focus on three key themes: (1)
Dynamics of Climate, (2) Climate Process Modeling, and (3) Data
Analysis and Data Assimilation. Dynamics of Climate addresses
critical climate processes and their interactions. Climate
Process Modeling undertakes the modeling of climate components
that have been underrepresented in extant climate models, such as
the multi-scale material structure of sea ice. Data Analysis and
Data Assimilation develops mathematical tools for analyzing
climate data and assimilating them in current climate models.
The Research Network aims to be a national resource, with
participants at thirteen U.S. universities. The investigators
work together as a virtual community that holds regular weekly
"webinars" and working meetings over the Internet. This
multi-year effort is expected to help in defining a research area
of "climate mathematics" and in educating a new generation of
mathematical researchers to meet the scientific challenges
associated with a changing climate.

This project is driven by the need to better understand the
Earth's climate system. Climate is the result of many
geophysical and chemical processes in the Earth's atmosphere,
oceans and biosphere. These processes evolve in time over many
scales, ranging from minutes to centuries, and interact in
multiple ways, most often nonlinearly. Feedback mechanisms, many
of which are poorly understood, further complicate the picture.
Because there is only one Earth, climate cannot be studied by
systematic experimentation; the only approach available to
climate researchers is through computational experiments. These
experiments are based on mathematical models, which must be
simple enough not to exceed the capabilities of today's advanced
computer architectures, while still incorporating the physical
and chemical processes that are essential for realistic climate
outcomes. The expertise of mathematical scientists in designing,
assessing and interpreting these models is critical. This
"Mathematics and Climate Research Network" helps engage the
mathematical sciences community to address the mathematical and
statistical issues of our changing climate. The Research Network
takes full advantage of current information technology;
communication and collaboration among the participants takes
place mostly remotely over the Internet.

Overview

The ambition of the 2010 NSF MCRN award was “no less than the creation of an area of applied mathematics”, using a new and original network structure that builds on existing expertise in geographically dispersed research groups. The Bowdoin PI, Zeeman, is one of the co-directors of MCRN. The clearest picture of MCRN’s achievements is given by the evaluation carried out by Philips Wyatt Knowlton, Inc. in 2015. The snapshot of their evaluation is attached. In the evaluation, MCRN members cite the following as extraordinary advantages of this kind of distributed initiative:

• Access to broad range of expertise not available on a student’s home campus,
• Support and mentoring by an extended mentoring team,
• Feeling of community of people with shared goals,
• Ability to forge new collaborations quickly and choose from large group of potential collaborators,
• Access to the resources needed to get into a new research area,
• Broadly-based support for seeking new opportunities.

What was achieved in the award period  serves as a model for how a new area can be defined and energized in a relatively short period of time. MCRN now serves as an infrastructure model, a research enterprise, a framework for education and training, and an international initiative. 

 

Intellectual Merit

The award provided the critical mass on which the MCRN was built, through postdoctoral fellowships and graduate student stipends, and it has forged strong bonds between the original 12 participating institutions. With a spirit of inclusion and transparency, the network has now grown to over 280 members from 135 institutions. There are 15 thriving research focus groups (RFGs), working and publishing on topics ranging from mathematical challenges in climate change research (e.g. data assimilation, non-smooth systems and cryosphere) to mathematical challenges for supporting sustainability decisions in the face of a changing climate (e.g. resilience, electric grid and food systems). Each of these focus groups is geographically dispersed and vertically integrated. There are also online seminars, reading groups, and a public engagement group. The integration of research, training and mentoring that generated such strikingly enthusiastic feedback in the 2015 network evaluation was achieved by a careful balance of network-wide activities and network-facilitated small group activities. 

Over 200 papers have resulted from this project. 

 

Broader Impacts

Preparing students to tackle urgent climate and sustainability problems that are more complex, multi-disciplinary and interwoven than those we are used to tackling ourselves is a non-trivial challenge, requiring profound intellectual courage on the part of the students and their mentors. It has been an especially rewarding aspect of MCRN to see our own students rapidly outgrow us in their interdisciplinary independence, as a direct result of their immersion in the MCRN community. 

Broadening their reach, Zeeman and other MCRN members also played key roles in the leadership team of the Mathematics of Planet Earth (MPE) initiative.The success and longevity of the MPE initiative is sealed by the founding of the SIAM activity group for the mathematics of planet Earth, of which all four founding officers are members of MCRN.

MCRN members at Bowdoin, a small liberal arts college, have benefitted tremendously from their interaction with MCRN. With the support of MCRN’s mentoring team structure, The PI has been able to offer more research opportunities to students, and on a wider range of topics, than she would have been able to offer alone. Bowdoin undergraduates have conducted independent research projects on paleoclimate; tipping points; resilience; fisheries and food systems. They have interacted with MCRN graduate students, postdocs and faculty through internet working groups, conferences, and research visits, giving the undergraduates real insight into graduate school at a critical transition moment in their careers. The social relevance of the MCRN topics has a track record of appealing to students, and especially to women and underrepresented minority groups in STEM fields, thereby contributing to recruitment and retention of those groups.

The Bowdoin PI, Zeeman, has played an active leadership role for the community. She is a co-director of MCRN, a member of the executive council of the Computational Sustainability Network (compsustnet), and a co-leader of the Mathematics of Planet Earth Initiative. She has  co-organised approximately 25 conferences, workshops and minisyposia, and presented over 30 talks on mathematical challenges in climate, sustainability and decision support during the award period.
